content.text:
In the circuit shown below, each of the resistors has the same resistance.<image 1>A voltmeter with very high resistance is connected between two points in the circuit.Between which two points of connection would the voltmeter read zero?

A. Q and U
B. P and T
C. Q and W
D. S and U

To determine where the voltmeter would read zero, we need to consider the circuit's configuration and the behavior of the voltmeter. The voltmeter in this circuit is connected between points Q and U, which are connected to the same point P.

The voltmeter has a very high resistance, which means it will not affect the current flow through the circuit. Therefore, the voltmeter will not change the voltage across any point in the circuit.

Since the voltmeter is connected between points Q and U, and the circuit has the same resistance for all resistors, the voltage across the voltmeter will be the same as the voltage across the resistor R at point Q. Since the voltmeter has a very high resistance, it will not affect the voltage across the resistor R at point Q.

Therefore, the voltmeter will read zero between points Q and U.

The correct answer is:
A. Q and U
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
